campus_walk_1.text: The soft hum of distant conversations fills the air as Sage walks through the bustling campus. The spring semester has begun, but the weight of unfinished feelings from the fall still lingers. She adjusts her mint-green cardigan against the chill of the breeze.

campus_walk_2.speaker: Sage
campus_walk_2.text: Okay... Second semester, an experienced Freshman - now that I survived the first. I can handle this... right? Writing classes, reading classes, a ridiculously hard math class - all part of the fun? I am supposed to embrace this - love it even, so why does everything feel scary and overwhelming?

campus_walk_3.text: Students pass by, laughing, chatting easily. Sage's footsteps slow as a group of peers from her first semester cross her path—already deep in conversation.

campus_walk_4.speaker: Sage
campus_walk_4.text: They make it seem so easy. I would say hello, but…they do not seem at all worried about anything - I would be a downer to them… I should... keep moving.

campus_walk_5.text: A phone notification buzzes in her pocket, but she ignores it for now, focusing on the path ahead. She sighs quietly, her eyes scanning the campus, lingering on students who already seem at ease.

campus_walk_6.speaker: Sage
campus_walk_6.text: “I should feel better about this. But I don't.”

blake_encounter_1.text: As she approaches the dorms, Sage crosses paths with Blake who shares the same major as Sage —a sharp-eyed, confident student who is always at the top of the class. Blake spots her and approaches her wanting to talk about the great first semester.

blake_encounter_2.speaker: Blake
blake_encounter_2.text: “Hi Sage - Ready for another semester? I am so excited! I thought last semester was soooo much fun with all the new stuff we learned and the meaningful projects we were assigned, but this semester we get to do even more!”

blake_encounter_3.speaker: Sage
blake_encounter_3.text: Wow, she is exactly where I wish I were. Enjoying college, living the life, making the most of it all…that’s what I’m supposed to be - but I know I’m not - I don’t even belong in the same program as her - this could be soooo embarrassing - I would just die if she knew how inept I really am.

choices.text: Fake it till you Make it

blake_fakeit_1.speaker: Sage
blake_fakeit_1.text: “Oh of course - it will be great! And last semester was great too - if I choose to only think about the good times.”

blake_fakeit_2.speaker: Sage
blake_fakeit_2.text: Great - keep the positive thoughts in the front Sage….she does not need to see your insecurities.

blake_fakeit_3.speaker: Blake
blake_fakeit_3.text: “Okay, well, I guess I will see you later.”

blake_fakeit_4.text: Blake walks away, leaving Sage to her thoughts.

blake_honest_1.text: Sage stops and faces Blake, meeting her gaze with a newfound resolve.

blake_honest_2.speaker: Sage
blake_honest_2.text: “Well, I’m still here, but honestly, last semester was tough for me. I was just relieved to pull through.”

blake_honest_3.text: Blake raises an eyebrow, but offers encouragement

blake_honest_4.speaker: Blake
blake_honest_4.text: “You know, most of us were… struggling last semester. I think I finally figured out how to study. Chin up - we’ve all been there!”

blake_honest_6.text: Her words linger long after she’s gone.

blake_honest_7.text: Sage turns and walks away, her steps echoing as she goes.

dorm_arrival_1.text: Sage walks into her dorm lobby, the scent of old coffee lingers from the communal kitchen, a stale reminder of late-night study sessions.

dorm_arrival_2.text: She looks around — everyone seems busy with the first round of exams and project deadlines soon approaching. She eyes the calendar on the wall–

dorm_arrival_3.speaker: Sage
dorm_arrival_3.text: Three weeks into the semester — how can I already be so far behind?

dorm_arrival_4.text: Looking around she sees a few dorm-mates watching One Piece.

dorm_arrival_5.speaker: Sage
dorm_arrival_5.text: oooohhhh, I could just sit and join them and take a break for a while — I really love that show.

dorm_arrival_6.text: She checks her phone — a missed call from home and a reminder from a professor about an upcoming assignment.

dorm_arrival_7.speaker: Sage
dorm_arrival_7.text: “Great. Deadline approaching — I am always behind and it has to be done well or there goes my grade, my GPA, my entire academic standing — lose my scholarship — get kicked out — never get a good job — “aaaaaaaccccckkkkkk!”

dorm_arrival_9.text:
She heads upstairs, swiping her keycard and pushing open the door to her dorm room.
It’s quiet — almost too quiet.

dorm_arrival_10.text: Sage sighs as she sits at her desk, the assignment staring back at her. The instructions seem to blur together as Sage forces her attention back into place.

dorm_striveA_1.speaker: Sage
dorm_striveA_1.text: I better get started, I know that I need the A or I will not be happy.

dorm_striveA_2.text: She decides to work on the project for several hours.

dorm_striveA_3.text: Sage stands up and stretches, she is finally satisfied that she will get an A on the assignment. She looks at the time — it's late — after midnight — did she even eat dinner?

dorm_reasonable_1.speaker: Sage
dorm_reasonable_1.text: Since this is due tomorrow, I better prioritize my time. I can start the assignment and set a timer to take a dinner break in one hour so I can come back and evaluate my progress with a clear mind.

dorm_reasonable_2.text: Sage works on the assignment for an hour and stops for dinner before returning to the assignment

dorm_reasonable_3.speaker: Sage
dorm_reasonable_3.text: Have I met the criteria — let me check — yep — but I could add to this and really wow my professor. That would ensure I got an A.

dorm_reasonable_4.text: She looks at the time — it's 7:30 and her roommates are talking about the weekend — she looks at her assignment and decides it is sufficient. She joins her friends and connects with them before getting ready for bed.

phone_call_1.text: The next morning, Sage wakes as her phone buzzes again—this time, a text from home. She hesitates before answering, staring at the screen as if it might bite.

phone_call_2.speaker: Sage
phone_call_2.text: What do they want now? A progress report? A lecture on how I’m not living up to my potential?

phone_call_3.text: The phone rings as Sage hesitates. Finally, she answers, her voice laced with a forced lightness.

phone_call_4.speaker: Parent
phone_call_4.text: “Hey, sweetheart. How’s the grind? Are you feeling okay about your schoolwork?”

phone_call_5.text: The concerned voice reminds Sage that even her family is worried.

phone_vague_1.speaker: Sage
phone_vague_1.text: “Oh, you know…same old thing, nothing too exciting. I am just busy as always.”

phone_vague_2.speaker: Parent
phone_vague_2.text: “Well, busy is good. Just stay focused. We know you can do this. You’ve always been so bright.”

phone_vague_4.speaker: Sage
phone_vague_4.text: Soooo bright, so capable, can do it all — can’t you see that does NOT help! I am drowning here and talking just feels like more expectations to live up to.

phone_vague_5.speaker: Sage
phone_vague_5.text: “Well, I’m sorry to cut you short, but I have to get to a study group. Talk to you later, love you.”

phone_honest_1.speaker: Sage
phone_honest_1.text: “It’s...kind of overwhelming, honestly. I feel like I’m already behind.”

phone_honest_2.speaker: Parent
phone_honest_2.text: “Well, that’s normal. You’re doing fine, Sage. You always put too much pressure on yourself. Don’t overthink it. Just keep your head down and work hard - you know, do the best you can.”

phone_honest_4.speaker: Sage
phone_honest_4.text: Can’t you see that “doing my best” all the time is exhausting, not to mention impossible to maintain. I am eventually going to fail and let you down. (feels tears welling)

phone_honest_5.speaker: Parent
phone_honest_5.text: “You’ll be fine. Just remember why you’re there. To get a good education, to build a future. We’re all rooting for you.”

phone_honest_6.speaker: Sage
phone_honest_6.text: “I know you are, and I know you believe in me, but I really feel like I am going to burn out. Sometimes I feel so scared to let you down — I really want to make you proud of me.”

phone_honest_7.speaker: Parent
phone_honest_7.text: “Oh Sage. No honey, really, there is nothing you can do to make me love you less and I am already so VERY proud of you. You only have to make yourself proud. Make choices that you believe in, not the ones you think we want from you. Sage - hear me on this - we love you unconditionally - you are enough.”

phone_honest_8.speaker: Sage
phone_honest_8.text: Why does everything feel so heavy? Like I’m carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders. It’s not that I don’t feel loved, I just - well - I hope I don't let anyone down.

phone_call_6.text: Regardless of the choice, the call ends with a feeling of subtle but familiar pressure. Sage stares at the phone after hanging up.

social_invite_1.text: It’s now Friday and campus is emptying quickly as students rush to get to their weekend plans. A notification pops up: a group from one of Sage’s classes is organizing a casual study meet-up at the campus coffee shop.

social_invite_2.text: The message reads: "Join us for some study and chill! No pressure!" She hovers over the message, torn between the allure of connection and the safety of isolation.

social_accept_1.speaker: Sage
social_accept_1.text: Sage types a quick reply: "I’m in. See you guys there!"

social_accept_2.speaker: Sage
social_accept_2.text: Maybe this’ll help. I could certainly use some group study since I am not doing great with the subject matter. And maybe if I’m around other people, I won’t feel so alone. I can’t do everything alone, right?

social_accept_3.text: Sage puts her phone away, packing her backpack and primping up a bit before heading out.

social_accept_4.text: Sage gets back late, the study session was helpful but now she is exhausted - and heads straight to bed.

social_ignore_1.text: She closes the message without replying, her thumb hovering over the "mute notifications" button.

social_ignore_2.speaker: Sage
social_ignore_2.text: No point in going, I’ll just make a fool of myself. I can figure it out myself, I always do. Besides, socializing is so taxing!

social_ignore_3.text: Her decision lingers as the silence feels heavier now. She works on homework for a while and then heads to bed.

dream_seq_transition.text: That night...Sage is tossing in her bed...surreal and emotional dreams plaguing her sleep.

dream_entrance.text: WELCOME to the Stress & Anxiety Carnival

imposter_challenge_1.text: Sage is filled with trepidation as she enters the big top through the heavy tent flaps. The darkness clears and Sage sees…

imposter_challenge_2.text: …a row of kiosks and booths in their own exclusive food area of the carnival. She immediately feels that she has no business being here, this is for all of the authentic academic folks.

imposter_challenge_3.speaker: Sage
imposter_challenge_3.text: “What in the actual hell am I doing in this area?!?!”

imposter_challenge_4.speaker: Sage
imposter_challenge_4.text: “I know I don't deserve to have this meal ticket  — I’m not a summa cum laude, and standing here I look like I am trying to pass myself off as something I’m not.”

imposter_challenge_5.text: Sage reads the various options. They all look prestigious and haughty.

imposter_challenge_6.speaker: Sage
imposter_challenge_6.text: Are there any that are more private — where I can't see everyone else — and they can't see me?

imposter_challenge_7.speaker: Sage
imposter_challenge_7.text: “Oh nevermind, I am not that hungry anyways.”

imposter_challenge_8.text: Sage opens her eyes and tries to place her surroundings. She realizes that she was dreaming and thinks about how hungry she is. What a strange dream — she’s not even on a meal plan.

imposter_challenge_9.speaker: Sage
imposter_challenge_9.text: But it was somewhat accurate — if she did try to go somewhere she shouldn’t be, then she would probably get out of there before anyone saw her — hungry or not.

perfect_challenge_1.text: Sage stands in line at the booth that reads “Perfection Contest” with two full lines of contestants.

perfect_challenge_2.speaker: Sage
perfect_challenge_2.text: “I am such an idiot. What am I doing in this line? This is stupid and impossible. I should have gotten here sooner. That was a big mistake.”

perfect_challenge_3.speaker: Sage
perfect_challenge_3.text: “I knew I had to be first in line - I knew that this is the contest I had to win and now I am so screwed. Figures — all because I didn’t get up early enough. I am never far enough ahead - always playing catch up - always falling short.”

perfect_challenge_4.speaker: Sage
perfect_challenge_4.text: “Wow, all these people were better than me at planning this out. I don't know why I thought I could do this.”

perfect_challenge_5.speaker: Sage
perfect_challenge_5.text: “Really, I do know why — I need to have this accolade. This is the proof that I did it right. This is the evidence that I am worthy.”

perfect_challenge_6.speaker: Sage
perfect_challenge_6.text: Sage wakes up and looks around her messy dorm room. Self critical as always, she starts to berate herself for not keeping up. She turns over and pulls the covers over her head. Sometimes the pressure that she puts on herself and others is so overwhelming - she tries to shut out the world and go back to sleep, but she keeps thinking about falling short of her own expectations and continues to criticize herself.

pleaser_challenge_1.text: Sage enters the carnival and sees herself  slumped at the pie-eating contest table, she looks ill like she overate. Empty pie pans and crumb-covered plates surround her. The scorecards indicate that she has gotten an 8 and a 9.

pleaser_challenge_2.speaker: Sage
pleaser_challenge_2.text: “Okay — those scores are okay — I did it.”

pleaser_challenge_3.speaker: Sage
pleaser_challenge_3.text: “I sure feel awful though — my stomach is so sick — and everyone is looking at me  — oh why do I keep doing things that feel bad just to make others happy?”

pleaser_challenge_4.speaker: Sage
pleaser_challenge_4.text: “At least no one is calling me out and I am not in a confrontation. That really is the most important thing.”

pleaser_challenge_5.text: Sage tries to quietly exit the area — suddenly she is running and crying. She feels her legs burning and she can't seem to catch her breath. Exhausted and falls to the ground.

pleaser_challenge_6.text: Sage wakes up with her heart pounding and cold from sweat — like she just went for a run. Knowing that she won't be going back to sleep, she heads to the shower to start her day.

antiSocial_challenge_1.text: Sage looks at the ferris wheel in the distance — each bucket has something written on it. She is excited to get on the ride and see the POV from the top — she heads to the line.

antiSocial_challenge_2.speaker: Sage
antiSocial_challenge_2.text: “I want to ride the ferris wheel — but what is that - wait - are those all…invites?”

antiSocial_challenge_3.speaker: Sage
antiSocial_challenge_3.text: “It’s almost my turn — I have to pick one, but which one? A Club Meeting — I should go since I missed the last one. Or the Study Group — I really need that. Date Night because I have not seen my guy in ages. Sheila’s Birthday Party - oh jeez - is that now?”

antiSocial_challenge_4.speaker: Sage
antiSocial_challenge_4.text: “Oh no — so many choices — exhausting — scary — decisions — the wheel never stops — not enough time — but I am really so lonely sometimes — and I don’t want to miss out.”

antiSocial_challenge_5.text: Sage opens her eyes and looks at the clock - it's five a.m. She feels compelled to open her calendar and scan her upcoming commitments. Her anxiety grows as she reads all the pending “Will you be attending this event? Maybe - Yes - No” options. Since she knows that she won't be going back to sleep, she decides to get up and start her day.

mentor_meetingImposter_1.text: Later, Sage meets with Professor Sharma, her mentor, who offers advice on managing stress, assignments, and life in general.

mentor_meetingImposter_2.text: The office is cluttered but warm—a stark contrast to Sage’s chaotic thoughts. Professor Sharma offers Sage a cup of tea and they begin to discuss her dream.

Imposter_Sage_advice_1.speaker: Professor Sharma
Imposter_Sage_advice_1.text: “Sage, many people feel inadequate and are afraid of falling short of their own or others’ expectations, but these should be temporary feelings, not a life mantra.”

Imposter_Sage_advice_3.speaker: Professor Sharma
Imposter_Sage_advice_3.text: “So, you have spoken to me before about feeling like an imposter and now you are dreaming about it. Perhaps we should get a bit more informed and try for a better understanding of these feelings? Do you know anyone else who feels similar to you?”

Imposter_Sage_advice_4.speaker: Sage
Imposter_Sage_advice_4.text: “No, not really. I suppose some other folks feel unworthy but I would never pry, and chance them feeling afraid of exposure. It seems like that would be unkind. Well, it would definitely feel terrible to me.”

Imposter_Sage_advice_5.speaker: Professor Sharma
Imposter_Sage_advice_5.text: “Actually, it’s not some people, but many, who relate to those types of feelings, Sage. ”

Imposter_Sage_advice_6.speaker: Professor Sharma
Imposter_Sage_advice_6.text: “Would it surprise you to know that people like Michelle Obama, Tina Fey, Sonya Sotomayer, and Tom Hanks have discussed having imposter feelings?”

Imposter_Sage_advice_7.speaker: Sage
Imposter_Sage_advice_7.text: “Really, wow. That seems misplaced — why would successful people think that they are not as good as everyone seems to THINK they are?”

Imposter_Sage_advice_8.speaker: Professor Sharma
Imposter_Sage_advice_8.text: “Well, do you think they are unworthy?”

Imposter_Sage_advice_9.speaker: Sage
Imposter_Sage_advice_9.text: “No, of course not, they already proved they are fantastic with the evidence of their accomplishments.”

Imposter_Sage_advice_10.speaker: Professor Sharma
Imposter_Sage_advice_10.text: “But what if they think that they will be unmasked as an imposter at any minute? Perhaps that their successes are flukes, or that they’re just hiding their failures really well?”

Imposter_Sage_advice_11.speaker: Sage
Imposter_Sage_advice_11.text: “I suppose I could see that, but what could they, or I, do about it?”

Imposter_Sage_advice_12.speaker: Professor Sharma
Imposter_Sage_advice_12.text: “You are NOT an imposter, Sage, but to believe that you may need to look at making some individual changes. There are lots of therapies and research models you could choose from but I can get you started with a couple that I have used.”

Imposter_Sage_advice_13.speaker: Sage
Imposter_Sage_advice_13.text: “You’ve used? You mean you’ve felt this way too?”

Imposter_Sage_advice_14.speaker: Professor Sharma
Imposter_Sage_advice_14.text: “I sure have, I told you it's surprising how many of us there are! Lets see, I remember using a research model called “Reflect, Plan, Change” and I remember doing an acceptance  and commitment therapy (ACT) exercise with a counselor I knew. Which one interests you?”

act_exercise_1.speaker: Professor Sharma
act_exercise_1.text: “My therapist had me write my imposter thoughts on a piece of paper and destroy it. It symbolized the non-permanence of such thoughts and feelings.”

act_exercise_2.speaker: Professor Sharma
act_exercise_2.text: “They can be acknowledged and changed. The thing is, the purpose was to accept the presence of the thoughts but remember that they are just that — thoughts — not facts.”

act_exercise_3.speaker: Professor Sharma
act_exercise_3.text: “So it can be as easy to change them as crumpling up a piece of paper, if you practice.”

mentor_meetingImposter_3.speaker: Sage
mentor_meetingImposter_3.text: “Okay… I’ll try. I’ll try to be honest with myself and I will try to use your advice. Thanks, Professor.”

mentor_meetingImposter_4.speaker: Professor Sharma
mentor_meetingImposter_4.text: “That’s all anyone can ask. Your vulnerability is your strength Sage, you will grow through this. And remember, every college student I know is facing something — it's just the nature of the journey.”

mentor_meetingPerfect_1.text: Later, Sage meets with Professor Sharma, her mentor, who offers advice on managing stress, assignments, and life in general.

mentor_meetingPerfect_2.text: The office is cluttered but warm — a stark contrast to Sage’s chaotic thoughts. Professor Sharma offers Sage a cup of tea and they begin to discuss her dream.

Perfect_Sage_advice_1.speaker: Professor Sharma
Perfect_Sage_advice_1.text: “You don’t have to be perfect, Sage. Just be honest with yourself. Let your true voice come through.”

Perfect_Sage_advice_2.speaker: Sage
Perfect_Sage_advice_2.text: “Honest... right. Because that's easy. Everyone expects me to be perfect.”

Perfect_Sage_advice_3.speaker: Professor Sharma
Perfect_Sage_advice_3.text: “Who is everyone, Sage? And what do you expect from yourself?”

Perfect_Sage_advice_4.speaker: Sage
Perfect_Sage_advice_4.text: “Well, I suppose, even I expect to be my best self - all the time. I like getting great grades and being a good friend and family member, and feeling like I succeeded.”

Perfect_Sage_advice_5.speaker: Professor Sharma
Perfect_Sage_advice_5.text: “Is it possible to be perfect? In your dream, do you expect that you would ever reach the front of the line — or do you think you know that it is impossible and that your expectation was always unrealistic?”

Perfect_Sage_advice_6.speaker: Sage
Perfect_Sage_advice_6.text: “I do know that it's impossible. I think it's ridiculous to even consider being perfect. I think that's why I am so angry with myself — I feel stupid and like I should know better.”

Perfect_Sage_advice_7.speaker: Sage
Perfect_Sage_advice_7.text: “You know, there are a couple of things you could try to be less of a perfectionist and hopefully happier.”

Perfect_Sage_advice_8.speaker: Professor Sharma
Perfect_Sage_advice_8.text: “I am concerned about how hard you are on yourself and how much pressure you create. Have you ever heard of the Pareto Principle or considered keeping a Thought Diary?”

thought_diary_1.speaker: Professor Sharma
thought_diary_1.text: “A thought diary is one way to see your negative thoughts. Once you acknowledge your own thoughts, you can see their effect on how you feel and act.”

thought_diary_2.speaker: Professor Sharma
thought_diary_2.text: “You can learn to challenge your own negative thinking and make a conscious effort to stop unhelpful thoughts and create more grace for yourself. It takes patience, but can be very insightful.”

pareto_principle_1.speaker: Professor Sharma
pareto_principle_1.text: “The Pareto Principle helps people focus on what is most important, and save time.”

pareto_principle_2.speaker: Professor Sharma
pareto_principle_2.text: “You focus on the 20 percent of your tasks that  will yield the best 80 percent of results and you take things to 80 percent quality and move on — allowing yourself to return to the task, but only if time allows and decreasing the pressure to do everything every time.”

mentor_meetingPerfect_3.speaker: Sage
mentor_meetingPerfect_3.text: “Okay… I’ll try. I’ll try to be honest with myself and I will try to use your advice. Thanks, Professor.”

mentor_meetingPerfect_4.speaker: Professor Sharma
mentor_meetingPerfect_4.text: “That’s all anyone can ask. Your vulnerability is your strength Sage, you will grow through this. And remember, every college student I know is facing something — it's just the nature of the journey.”

mentor_meetingPleaser_1.text: Later, Sage meets with Professor Sharma, her mentor, who offers advice on managing stress, assignments, and life in general.

mentor_meetingPleaser_2.text: The office is cluttered but warm—a stark contrast to Sage’s chaotic thoughts. Professor Sharma offers Sage a cup of tea and they begin to discuss her dream.

Pleaser_Sage_advice_1.speaker: Professor Sharma
Pleaser_Sage_advice_1.text: “I know that you are a very kind and compassionate person Sage, those are wonderful qualities that I admire about you.”

Pleaser_Sage_advice_2.speaker: Professor Sharma
Pleaser_Sage_advice_2.text: “I wonder if you realize how much you do for others at your own expense. It’s like you are eating pie until you are literally sick. When you feel unhappy about something, I believe it’s because your actions aren't aligned with your values.”

Pleaser_Sage_advice_3.speaker: Sage
Pleaser_Sage_advice_3.text: “I am not sure what to do about that, or even how to see when it may happen, since I find myself unhappy after the fact.”

Pleaser_Sage_advice_4.speaker: Professor Sharma
Pleaser_Sage_advice_4.text: “Pleasing others is an extension of being nice. It's not inherently bad behavior. However, if you do things for others to the point of being unhappy, it can be harmful to your well-being.”

Pleaser_Sage_advice_5.speaker: Professor Sharma
Pleaser_Sage_advice_5.text: “Perhaps you would consider trying some things to help you take care of yourself?”

Pleaser_Sage_advice_6.speaker: Sage
Pleaser_Sage_advice_6.text: “Sure, I guess, but I think I will be okay if I just stay the course.”

Pleaser_Sage_advice_7.speaker: Professor Sharma
Pleaser_Sage_advice_7.text: “There are a couple of things I can suggest. One I call the Taking Your Time technique and the other I refer to as Structuring Your Boundaries. Which one would you like me to tell you about?”

time_1.speaker: Professor Sharma
time_1.text: “Taking your time involves not answering requests with a yes or no answer, but answering them with questions.”

time_2.speaker: Professor Sharma
time_2.text: “Does this feel stressful to me? How long will it take and do I have that much time? Can I afford the opportunity cost of saying ‘yes’?”

time_3.speaker: Professor Sharma
time_3.text: “You give yourself the time to gather more information and think about your own desires, instead of automatically agreeing out of a fear of rejection.”

boundaries_1.speaker: Professor Sharma
boundaries_1.text: “Structuring your boundaries requires actual limitations on real life commitments. For example, setting a timer to start or stop activities, time-boxing conversations, creating a schedule, or even making yourself use prepared responses to common situations.”

boundaries_2.speaker: Professor Sharma
boundaries_2.text: “You can practice small steps. Saying things that are not your usual responses like ‘maybe next time’ ‘I gotta pass’ or ‘I really do not have the bandwidth for that right now’.”

boundaries_3.speaker: Professor Sharma
boundaries_3.text: “Instead of always making time and energy for others, you can tell yourself it’s okay that you did not have time to meet a friend because you had to take care of a personal priority.”

boundaries_4.speaker: Professor Sharma
boundaries_4.text: “Here is one that I bet feels uncomfortable: you can try committing to not making excuses. Literally just saying ‘No’ as your entire response, with that winning smile of yours of course.”

mentor_meetingPleaser_3.speaker: Sage
mentor_meetingPleaser_3.text: “Okay… I’ll try. I’ll try to be honest with myself and I will try to use your advice. Thanks, Professor.”

mentor_meetingPleaser_4.speaker: Professor Sharma
mentor_meetingPleaser_4.text: “That’s all anyone can ask. Your vulnerability is your strength Sage, you will grow through this. And remember, every college student I know is facing something — it's just the nature of the journey.”

mentor_meetingAntiSocial_1.text: Later, Sage meets with Professor Sharma, her mentor, who offers advice on managing stress, assignments, and life in general.

mentor_meetingAntiSocial_2.text: The office is cluttered but warm — a stark contrast to Sage’s chaotic thoughts. Professor Sharma offers Sage a cup of tea and they begin to discuss her dream.

antiSocial_Sage_advice_1.speaker: Professor Sharma
antiSocial_Sage_advice_1.text: “That seems like a pretty straightforward dream Sage. I think you are correct in noticing that you feel overwhelmed — by both a want, and an expectation, to participate while still needing to recharge alone— like most introverts do!”

antiSocial_Sage_advice_2.speaker: Sage
antiSocial_Sage_advice_2.text: “Yeah, the huge ferris wheel sure felt overwhelming.”

antiSocial_Sage_advice_3.speaker: Professor Sharma
antiSocial_Sage_advice_3.text: “Frankly, I am more concerned with how you feel and talk to yourself when you do participate and the fears that push you to avoid participation.”

antiSocial_Sage_advice_4.speaker: Professor Sharma
antiSocial_Sage_advice_4.text: “But how could I possibly change that?”

antiSocial_Sage_advice_5.speaker: Professor Sharma
antiSocial_Sage_advice_5.text: “Well, I have a couple of ideas. Two websites come to mind for you to check out — one is Charisma on Command and the other is Project Helping.”

charisma_1.speaker: Professor Sharma
charisma_1.text: “Charisma on Command is a program that has a YouTube channel and an instructional curriculum through Charisma University.”

charisma_2.speaker: Professor Sharma
charisma_2.text: “The premise is that you can learn charisma, the skills you need to feel more confident, and have greater social success. It’s all about practice, just like everything else!”

projectHelping_1.speaker: Professor Sharma
projectHelping_1.text: “Project Helping is a program that connects people to volunteer opportunities. Helping others is a very powerful tool for improving mental wellness overall.”

projectHelping_2.speaker: Professor Sharma
projectHelping_2.text: “The website makes it very easy to volunteer and helping can have immediate positive effects.”

mentor_meetingAntiSocial_3.speaker: Sage
mentor_meetingAntiSocial_3.text: “Okay… I’ll try. I’ll try to be honest with myself and I will try to use your advice. Thanks, Professor.”

mentor_meetingAntiSocial_4.speaker: Professor Sharma
mentor_meetingAntiSocial_4.text: “That’s all anyone can ask. Your vulnerability is your strength Sage, you will grow through this. And remember, every college student I know is facing something — it's just the nature of the journey.”

dorm_finalProj_1.text: As the semester dwindles to a close, Sage sits in her dorm, staring at the prompt for her final project.

dorm_finalProj_2.text: It stares back, reading “Interpret a personal challenge in a creative medium and write a synopsis of that challenge, including what you learned from the experience.”

dorm_finalProj_3.speaker: Sage
dorm_finalProj_3.text: “Well, I've been here before and I know that I can handle this. I just need to decide where to start.”

dorm_finalProj_4.speaker: Sage
dorm_finalProj_4.text: I have faced challenges from so many of my experiences. I have done hard assignments. I have navigated tricky social situations. I have pushed my comfort zone and carried old responsibilities. I have even attempted to be more honest with myself. This is not straight-forward for me.

dorm_finalProj_5.text: Sage flips through her journal and reviews her entries.

dorm_finalProj_6.text: She immediately recollects how much work it took to try and take the time to reflect and plan before she would act on her feelings. Her Imposter Syndrome is so frustrating. She starts thinking about how hard acceptance is when she feels pressure.

dorm_finalProj_7.text: She reads about her Imposter Syndrome challenges like talking about subjects that she does not know much about, or sitting in a math class and being the last one to get the answer.

dorm_finalProj_8.text: Her journal states “You got the same answer! Remember this!”  and she smiles at her own demand. It didn’t matter now — she did not have any more math classes to take. She really started thinking about herself differently when she changed to a bigger picture point of view.

dorm_finalProj_9.text: She looks up at the clock and realizes that she has been reading for awhile. The words blur as anxiety begins to churn inside her. She takes a deep breath and looks down at the journal in her hands.

dorm_finalProj_10.speaker: Sage
dorm_finalProj_10.text: “Wait, this very journal is a reminder that I do not need to be perfect, in fact I started keeping it in order to remember that I can do a good job and succeed without working to the bone out of fear.”

dorm_finalProj_11.speaker: Sage
dorm_finalProj_11.text: This and the time management and efficiency tools have been so helpful — I certainly feel better than I did last semester. I hope it's even better next semester.

dorm_finalProj_12.speaker: Sage
dorm_finalProj_12.text: I need to reset my thinking. “I suppose I could call home and see what everyone is up to. Maybe hearing some encouragement will help me clarify the things that I have learned.”

dorm_finalProj_13.speaker: Sage
dorm_finalProj_13.text: But if my mom asks about how much I have done, I will feel like I failed her…again.

dorm_finalProj_14.speaker: Sage
dorm_finalProj_14.text: “She will check on my progress, tell me to stay on top of things, tell me she believes in me and imply judgement about my choices. Oh jeez. Maybe it's not a good idea.”

dorm_finalProj_15.speaker: Sage
dorm_finalProj_15.text: “But if I set a boundary and am honest with her maybe it could go well. I could tell her up front that I need her to tell me all the things she thinks I learned this semester, or is proud of me for accomplishing, and warn her that I need her to curtail any judgement or criticism at the moment.”

dorm_finalProj_16.text: Sage throws the journal on the bed and grabs her phone, but the page that is opened catches her eye. It reads “ProjectHelping.org” in big letters across the page.

dorm_finalProj_17.speaker: Sage
dorm_finalProj_17.text: “That's it. That's what has taught me the most, had the greatest positive impact on my life, and it's what I am the most proud of too.”

dorm_finalProj_18.speaker: Sage
dorm_finalProj_18.text: “I think I was overwhelmed with obligations and kept feeling afraid of letting everyone down — I preferred to be alone and just avoid altogether. Volunteering was such a great decision.”

dorm_finalProj_19.speaker: Sage
dorm_finalProj_19.text: “I have learned so much about myself and all the different aspects of me. I liked myself before, but I kept falling into stress and anxiety traps that would steal my happiness. I wonder how I can use this project to show my insights.”

dorm_finalProj_20.text: Sage glances at the creative prompt assignment. She imagines either a chaotic abstract that channels her stress and anxiety into her art, or a happily ever after visualization piece that expresses her long term goal.

dorm_finalProj_21.text: Her expression is a mix of uncertainty and a flicker of self-awareness. She decides to just start drawing and let her art decide.

choices.text: Artwork representing Sage's stress and anxiety

stress_art_1.text: A chaotic representation of all the aspects of stress and anxiety. This piece overuses color to symbolize an over-saturation, and the character is sick and anguished to the point of losing touch and becoming a static background. Sage looks at it and feels more motivated and competent than ever as she keeps this larger-than-life wretchedness at bay. She confidently turns in her final project with a smile of satisfaction.

happy_art_1.text: A smiling visualization of a peaceful Sage. The drawing exudes a sense of joyful freedom and self-expression, with dynamic movement and bold, cheerful energy. The character's pose and bright colors convey a carefree spirit, capturing a moment of confidence. Sage looks at it and can feel herself in that moment — that is the feeling she reminds herself to keep in mind.

closing_1.text: Sage reflects on her choices this semester — was she honest with herself? With others? Does she like the way she is living her life? Does she find her joy?

closing_2.speaker: Sage
closing_2.text: I suppose I really do like where I am standing right now. Maybe…I’m more in control than I thought. It seems as if all of my choices are part of the same challenge, to take care of myself and better my own well-being.

closing_3.speaker: Sage
closing_3.text: “Well, any ride worth taking is full of twists and turns, and a good mentor can certainly smooth out the bumps, but today, I am in a peaceful headspace.”

closing_4.text: Sage looks across the courtyard and sees Blake and some other classmates in a group outside the library. One of them motions to her to join them and she changes course with a nod and a smile.

closing_5.speaker: Sage
closing_5.text: “Really it's not that hard to find my ‘Chill’ — it's actually much easier when I remember that we are all in this together.”
